Can Voyager restructure and return? 

Tell us why below üëá

A restructuring plan announced Monday would compensate users for missing crypto with shares of Voyager equity and Voyager tokens.

That‚Äôs unlikely to leave users particularly happy, though it might give them an incentive to continue using the service.
https://t.co/k7Aeb0LD2L

Voyager told the court it plans to mount a comeback. 

A Chapter 11 restructuring would allow Voyager to shed debt and restructure itself, rather than having to liquidate its assets.  https://t.co/k7Aeb0LD2L

üìÖ  Then on July 6, Voyager filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in New York, estimating that it had more than 100,000 creditors and somewhere between $1 billion and $10 billion in assets. 
https://t.co/hPublflvHu https://t.co/Z31AjSclHY

üìÖ On June 23, Voyager lowered daily withdrawal limits from $25,000 to $10,000 per day. It was meant to buy the company time.

üìÖ On July 1, it froze all customer withdrawals and trading to ‚Äúavoid irreparable damage to the Debtors‚Äô business."
https://t.co/QEBlX5kdNt

Making matters worse, Celsius was falling apart at the same time. 

üìÖ On June 12, Celsius froze customer withdrawals, shaking broader confidence in lenders and prompting Voyager‚Äôs clients to run for safety. 
https://t.co/ojss34mVHh

To stop the bleeding, Voyager brokered a nearly $500 million loan facility with Alameda in mid-June to support its short-term finances. 

It was a ‚Äúpartial solution‚Äù to contagion-fueled liquidity issues exacerbated by the greater crypto market rout. https://t.co/AGVyRRY12x

üìÖ Things turned sour in June. Three Arrows Capital was down bad across the board. 

It was also one of Voyager‚Äôs single largest lending customers.
https://t.co/v6xiwSMpb1

Voyager said it quickly moved to hedge its risk as crypto winter began in early 2022, in part by reducing loans and mitigating counterparty risk. 

This effort was successful ‚Äúin most instances.‚Äù 

Until it wasn‚Äôt. https://t.co/k7Aeb0LD2L

At its height, Voyager Digital boasted 3.5 million users and $5.9 billion in assets, comparable to a small regional bank.

So how did a once-mighty and well-regarded crypto lending outfit get here? https://t.co/k7Aeb0LD2L https://t.co/68llOjxOVV

Until recently, @investvoyager‚Äôs future looked bright. 

On July 1, it froze customer funds. 

Just days later, the company filed for bankruptcy protection in New York. üßµ https://t.co/k7Aeb0LD2L https://t.co/44NUowt7fj
